factoid: The convoyman took no notice of the word "general".
The convoyman shouted at the soldiers who were blocking his way.
The convoyman shouted "Hi there, boys! Keep to the left! Wait a bit.".
The soldiers were crowded together shoulder to shoulder.
The soldiers' bayonets were interlocking.
The soldiers moved over the bridge in a dense mass.
Prince Nesvítski looked down over the rails.
Prince Nesvítski saw the rapid, noisy little waves of the Enns.
The waves of the Enns were rippling and eddying round the piles of the bridge.
The waves of the Enns chased each other along.
Prince Nesvítski looked on the bridge.
Prince Nesvítski saw equally uniform living waves of soldiers.
The soldiers had shoulder straps.
The soldiers had covered shakos.
The soldiers had knapsacks.
The soldiers had bayonets.
The soldiers had long muskets.
The soldiers had faces with broad cheekbones.
The soldiers had faces with sunken cheeks.
The soldiers had faces with listless tired expressions.
The soldiers' feet moved through the sticky mud that covered the planks of the bridge.
An officer in a cloak with a face different from that of the men squeezed his way along through the waves of men.
The officer was like a fleck of white foam on the waves of the Enns.
A hussar on foot was carried through the waves of infantry.
An orderly was carried through the waves of infantry.
A townsman was carried through the waves of infantry.
The hussar, orderly, and townsman were like a chip of wood whirling in the river.
An officers’ or company’s baggage wagon was piled high, leather covered, and hemmed in on all sides.
The baggage wagon moved across the bridge.
The baggage wagon was like a log floating down the river.
The Cossack said "It's as if a dam had burst".
The Cossack asked "Are there many more of you to come?".
A waggish soldier in a torn coat replied "A million all but one!".
The waggish soldier winked.
The waggish soldier passed on.
The waggish soldier was followed by an old man.
The old soldier said to a comrade that if the enemy begins popping at the bridge now, the comrade will forget to scratch himself.
The old soldier was dismal.
The old soldier passed on.
Another soldier, sitting on a cart, came after the old soldier.
An orderly running behind the cart and fumbling in the back of it said "Where the devil have the leg bands been shoved to?".
The orderly also passed on with the wagon.
Some merry soldiers who had evidently been drinking came.
A soldier whose greatcoat was well tucked up said gaily, with a wide swing of his arm, "And then, old fellow, he gives him one in the teeth with the butt end of his gun...".
Another soldier answered "Yes, the ham was just delicious" with a loud laugh.
The soldiers passed on.
Prince Nesvítski did not learn who had been struck on the teeth.
Prince Nesvítski did not learn what the ham had to do with the teeth.
A sergeant said angrily and reproachfully, "Bah! How they scurry. He just sends a ball and they think they'll all be killed.".
A young soldier with an enormous mouth said "As it flies past me, Daddy, the ball I mean.".
The young soldier hardly refrained from laughing.
The young soldier felt like dying of fright.
The young soldier bragged of having been frightened.
The young soldier passed on.
A cart unlike any that had gone before followed.
The cart was a German cart.
The cart had a pair of horses led by a German.
The cart seemed loaded with a whole houseful of effects.
A fine brindled cow with a large udder was attached to the cart behind.
A woman with an unweaned baby was sitting on some feather beds.
An old woman was sitting on some feather beds.
A healthy German girl with bright red cheeks was sitting on some feather beds.
The fugitives were allowed to pass by special permission.
The eyes of all the soldiers turned toward the women.
All soldiers' remarks related to the woman with an unweaned baby and the healthy German girl with bright red cheeks.
Every face bore almost the same smile.
Every face expressed unseemly thoughts about the women.
A soldier said "Just see, the German sausage is making tracks, too!".
Another soldier said "Sell me the missis" addressing the German.
The German was angry and frightened.
The German strode energetically along with downcast eyes.
A soldier said "See how smart she's made herself! Oh, the devils!".
A soldier said "There, Fedótov, you should be quartered on them!".
A soldier said "I have seen as much before now, mate!".
An infantry officer who was eating an apple and half smiling as he looked at the handsome girl asked "Where are you going?".
The German closed his eyes.
The German signified that he did not understand.
The infantry officer said "Take it if you like" giving the girl an apple.
